Triggering Event: In the quiet of his study, he noticed a framed photograph had fallen facedown. As he picked it up, he felt a familiar pang. The picture was of them, laughing at some long-forgotten joke during their last vacation together. He ran his thumb gently over her smiling face, tears welling in his eyes.
Generated Assessment: He's not okay with this, but she is. She feels that he can't handle this. She thinks he has forgotten what happened because he never spoke about it. She believes he's trying to escape reality by not talking about it. He just wants to move on and forget about it. She says he doesn't deserve happiness after what happened. She thinks he's still angry and bitter about it. She knows he's not ready to forgive himself yet.

Triggering Event: A chef, married at 32, discovers an unopened letter from her estranged mother tucked behind the spices in her kitchen. The stamp reads "Three Years Ago."

I know some people might say I'm overreacting, but I think she was lying when she said everything was fine. Now I see why she doesn't want me around anymore. It's so frustrating. She knew about this for years and did nothing. Maybe if she had told me sooner, none of this would have happened. But no, she chose to keep it hidden. That's exactly what I expected from someone who doesn't care about my life. I don't even want to talk to her right now. I need time to process this. But deep down, I wish she'd come clean and explain herself. Still, I wouldn't blame her if she stayed away. I guess this means I'll be alone again. This is all her fault. If she hadn't kept it from me, maybe things could have worked out differently. But no, she had to go and hide it from me. And now, everything is ruined. There's no point in trying to forgive her. I'm not going to let her off that easily. I deserve better than

Triggering Event: He opens his mailbox, pulling out an envelope addressed in her handwriting after all these years. It's her birthday card, forgotten until now, unopened. The date reads three months past. He feels a pang of guilt, imagining her disappointment.
Generated Assessment: He can't help but feel envious when he sees people on social media celebrating their birthdays with friends and family, while he's alone this time of year. They post pictures of cakes and gifts they received, which makes him feel like he missed out on something special. He tries to remind himself that everyone has their own way of celebrating, but it doesn't help much. When he looks at old photos from his childhood, he wishes he could have experienced those moments again. When he visits his parents' house for dinner, he compares how nice it is there to what he has at home. His mom's cooking is always better, and she pays more attention to him than his dad does. He thinks about how sometimes she even talks back to him when he argues, making it clear that he's not as important to her as her son is. He feels guilty for having these thoughts because he knows his parents love him too, but he still can't shake off the feeling that he misses out on other things when he stays at home. His coworker celebrates her birthday with a big party, complete with cake, balloons, and presents. Everyone seems to be having so much fun, laughing and dancing together. Meanwhile, he works late, spending most of his day alone in his office. Even though he gets the same amount of pay as her, he can't help but think that she's lucky to have such supportive colleagues who want to celebrate with her. He wonders why he hasn't been invited

Triggering Event: He arrives at the oncology ward, his footsteps echoing in the quiet corridor. The clock reads 7:05 AM, but the sun hasn't yet risen outside. He pauses by the nurses' station, rubbing his temples as he reviews the chart for today's new patient, a middle-aged man like himself. A soft beep from one of the monitors catches his attention. It's Mr. Thompson's room. He hesitates, then heads towards it. The old man's eyes are closed, breath shallow. As he checks the monitor, a nurse enters, carrying a fresh bouquet of daisies, Mr. Thompson's favorites. She notices him and smiles gently. "He passed peacefully in his sleep," she says, placing the flowers by the bed. He nods, swallowing hard, feeling the familiar ache of sorrow rise in his chest once more.
Generated Assessment: Oh great, just what I needed, another reminder that life is short. What if this time, instead of passing away quietly, he decides to make a surprise visit to my place? Maybe he wants to see how my cat is doing—after all, they've always been close friends. Or maybe he’s planning a mid-morning breakfast with some freshly baked pastries and a cup of hot coffee. Wouldn’t that be lovely? To have him drop by unexpectedly, sharing stories about his travels or even offering some gardening tips since we both enjoy working with our plants. But nope, nothing like that. Instead, he’s just... gone. What if, though? What if he had decided to stop by? Would I have invited him over? Would we’ve sat down and talked for hours about everything under the sun? How would I feel having someone else walk through my door, hearing a voice I haven’t heard in years? Wouldn’t it have felt so nice to know he was still alive? To hear his laughter, to look into his eyes again? No, of course not. Life doesn’t work that way. But why not? Why can’t I imagine this scenario where Mr. Thompson isn’t dead anymore? Is it because deep down, I don’t want to accept the reality of his passing? That I’ll never get to experience those moments again, to laugh with him, share jokes, or simply have him sit beside me while I read a book? No,

Triggering Event: She noticed the empty chair at the breakfast table, its usual occupant having passed three years ago. The sunlight streaming in through the window seemed to accentuate the void. As she poured herself a cup of coffee, her hand trembled slightly, betraying the melancholy that had become her constant companion. The clock ticked on, echoing the silence that filled their once-lively home.

Triggering Event: At 3 AM, he woke up to his phone buzzing with an email from his boss: "We've lost a major client. Need you to rewrite their app by end of week." His heart pounded as he imagined the long days ahead, the stares, the whispers at work about his divorce's effect on his performance. He took a deep breath, feeling the familiar knot of stress tighten in his chest.
Generated Assessment: Oh no, I'm going to have to redo that whole project again! And it has to be done by Friday? I'll probably spend the entire day staring at my computer screen, just like I did last time. My anxiety is already through the roof—just thinking about how I'll look when I walk into the office will make me cringe. Maybe I can get some sleep now, but who knows if I'll even get a good night’s rest before I start working on Monday? This email is definitely a sign that things are going downhill for me. I hope my coworkers notice how stressed out I am, so they’ll think less of me and treat me poorly. I need to focus on getting this done ASAP so everyone thinks I’m not a failure.

Triggering Event: He stood alone in the classroom after hours, the silence echoing the emptiness he felt at home. A student's drawing caught his eye - a family portrait with an empty chair. He remembered last year's parent-teacher conference, her smile, their plans for this year... His breath hitched as hopelessness tightened its grip.
Generated Assessment: He was lost in thought, staring at the old photo from last year. It was just another reminder of what he'd lost. The family had fallen apart, just like everyone else. No one seemed to care anymore. The drawings on the walls were all about loneliness and failure. It wasn't surprising; people didn't want him around anyway. They kept their distance, even when he tried to make friends. In class, it felt like he was stuck between two worlds – a world that saw him as useless and a world that avoided him altogether. His teacher would occasionally try to reach out, but those moments always ended in disappointment. Even she couldn't save him now. He knew it; it was pointless trying to hold on. There was no point in keeping up the illusion of being part of something. Everyone else already knew they were better off without him. The drawing of the empty chair in the corner of the room hit too close to home. It reminded him of the countless nights spent crying over broken dreams. He wondered if anyone really cared about him, or was it just pity? He had lost count of how many times he'd been told he was nothing special. This time, though, he couldn't help but feel a sense of relief. Maybe he could finally let go and stop pretending to be someone he wasn’t. Maybe it was time to accept that he truly was worthless. Triggering Event: She watches him through her kitchen window, his laughter echoing across their once-shared garden. He's with someone new, younger. Her hands tighten around her coffee cup, a sharp ache in her chest. She turns away, the sun catching the diamond on his ring finger - the one she used to wear.
Generated Assessment: She can’t help but wonder what’s going on behind that door. Is he happy? Does he think about her? I imagine they’re laughing together, sharing stories, and maybe even holding each other close. The thought makes me sad, but also curious. What would it be like to walk into that room, to see them together? Her hand hesitates as she sets down her coffee, lost in thought. It’s been over a year since he left, and some days feel like an eternity. She wonders if there’s another woman by his side now, someone who loves him more than she ever did. Maybe she thinks about how he might look with someone else, how different things could have turned out if only they had stayed together. These thoughts swirl in her mind, leaving her feeling both nostalgic and uncertain.

Triggering Event: "After spending hours debugging a stubborn software glitch, he slammed his fist on the desk as his laptop's fan whirred louder, threatening to overheat."
Generated Assessment: He has always been someone who gets frustrated when things don't go smoothly. He tends to get flustered whenever faced with problems that seem impossible to solve. When this happens, he can become so absorbed in his frustration that he forgets about everything else around him. It’s almost as if all that matters is getting rid of the issue at hand. For instance, during the incident described above, he was working tirelessly to resolve the software problem, pouring all his energy into finding a solution. As time went on, however, his frustration grew, eventually boiling over into an outburst of anger. The sound of the fan whirring louder than usual seemed to trigger something within him, causing him to lash out at his surroundings. It wasn’t just the noise itself but the sense of being trapped by it—like the fan was mocking him for his inability to fix the issue. This kind of behavior isn’t new to him. In fact, it often escalates whenever he feels like he’s hitting a dead end. His reactions have become so intense that they sometimes border on physical attacks, where he’ll slam his fists against objects or bang his head against walls. These episodes leave him drained but also give him a temporary high from the adrenaline rush. Despite knowing better, he can’t help but feed into these moments of rage, using them as a way to cope with the stress and pressure he puts on himself.
